results.title: Earl of Home
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
In an interview with Robert McKenzie, the Earl of Home, Britain’s Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, discusses present and future trends of the British Commonwealth and talks about some of the links and common aims that bind this family of nations together.

results.title: Sir John Cockroft
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Sir John Cockcroft, Director of Britain’s Atomic Research Establishment, answers question, put to him by Robert McKenzie, about construction and operation of the Calder Hall nuclear power station and the establishment of the Canadian Atomic Research Center at Chalk River. He talks about the far-reaching effects of Britain’s atomic power program on the everyday life of Britain and the Commonwealth whilst also making it clear that nuclear power is always more expensive - up to 10 times more - than fossil fuels. Closes with live footage of the Queen’s opening speech at Calder Hall.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Commonwealth Teleview Series - Visiting Harlow, a British satellite town, Christopher Chataway discusses this ‘modern’ building phenomenon with Frederick Gibberd, the city’s architect-planner. Chataway also interviews people living and working in the town, obtaining their views on this experiment in town planning.

results.title: The Commonwealth to the Commonwealth: Dr. Nkrumah
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
In this filmed interview marking the occasion of Ghana’s independence, Dr Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana’s first Prime Minister, answers questions put to him by Robert McKenzie about the nation’s political, economic and social achievements of the past and the present, and talks about this people’s hopes and aspirations for the future.

results.title: Sir Robert Scott
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Interviewed by Matthew Halton, Sir Robert Scott discusses his work as Britain’s Commissioner-General for South-East Asia. He talks about the importance of the area in Commonwealth and world affairs and some of the forces at work there such as SEATO (South East Asia Treaty Organisation) and the Colombo Plan.

results.title: The Commonwealth to the Commonwealth: Prince Philip's tour 1956
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
The world tour of HRH Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, as described by him on his return during a film and lantern-slide lecture of tour material shown to schoolchildren in London’s Royal Festival Hall. Shows inspection of British survey bases in Antarctica, a visit to a factory whaling ship, to islands in the South Atlantic, to Gambia, Malaya, New Guinea and Australia.

results.title: Boyfriends and girlfriends = L'Ami de mon amie
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Sofica Investimage and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
Illustrating the phrase “the friends of my friends are my friends”, “Boyfriends and girlfriends” begins as a comedy of perversity involving mismatched couples, in one of the new satellite cities ringing Paris. What makes it such fun is the freshness that Rohmer is able to bring to his film. There’s a vast dichotomy between what the characters say and do (or won’t say and won’t do) and the manicured man-made environment of Cergy-Pontoise. It is between those lines of dialogue and architecture that the film’s punch and spirit rests. Wistful, poignant and tender, this last chapter of Rohmer’s remarkable “Comedies et proverbes” cycle is a perfect place to take in the Gallic charm, elegant poise and cool wit of Eric Rohmer.

results.title: Full moon in Paris = Les Nuits de la pleine lune
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Les Films Ariane, Les Films du Losange and Acteurs Auteurs Associes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
He who has two women loses his soul is the cryptic message at the start of this film in Eric Rohmer’s “Comedies et proverbes” cycle. The he of the message is, in this instance, a she - Louise who cannot bear being “loved too much”. And so she plays a game of seduction with her two aspiring lovers, one of whom she loves too, in her own way. And what if they get tired of waiting, of being available? Pascale Ogier won the best actress award at Venice in 1984 for her role as Louise. She is supported by Tcheky Karyo and Fabrice Luchini.

results.title: Comedies et proverbes
results.brief_description: A series of six films, each of which illustrates a proverb by looking at the social manoeuvres of young French couples.

results.title: Pauline at the beach = Pauline a la plage
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Les Films Ariane and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
Third in Rohmer’s series “Comedies et Proverbes” this gentle comedy of adult sexual mores, has as its motto a saying of Chretien de Troyes “Qui trop parole, il se mesfait” “A wagging tongue bites itself”. Pauline joins her cousin for a holiday by the sea and has her fifteen year old eyes opened to the duplicity, hypocrisy and plain silliness of adult sexual politics. As the eponymous heroine, Amanda Langlet gives a beautifully subdued performance. Winner of Best Director award at the Berlin Film Festival in 1983. French language with English subtitles.
